article.title: Databricks Closes $7 Billion Round at $134 Billion Valuation and Bets the Agentic Era Needs a New Kind of Database
article.summary: Databricks raised $7 billion at a $134 billion valuation while launching Lakebase, a serverless PostgreSQL service for AI agent workloads, and expanding its Genie conversational data platform.
article.body_markdown:
## Overview

On February 9, 2026, Databricks announced the close of approximately $7 billion in financing — $5 billion in equity at a $134 billion valuation, plus roughly $2 billion in new debt capacity — making it one of the largest private software fundraises on record. The announcement arrived one week after the company made generally available Lakebase, a serverless PostgreSQL database purpose-built for AI agent workloads, and coincided with fresh details about Genie, its conversational data-query assistant. Together, the products and the capital signal Databricks' intent to move from a specialized analytics platform to the unified data backbone of the agentic enterprise.

## The Funding Round

According to [CNBC](https://www.cnbc.com/2026/02/09/databricks-completes-5-billion-funding-round-with-2-billion-in-debt.html), the equity portion drew participation from Goldman Sachs, Glade Brook Capital, Morgan Stanley, Neuberger Berman, and the Qatar Investment Authority, with JPMorgan leading the accompanying debt round. The $134 billion valuation matches Databricks' December 2025 financing, but the scale of fresh capital — $7 billion in total — underscores the confidence investors are placing in its growth trajectory.

Revenue tells a similar story. As reported in the company's [press release on PR Newswire](https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/databricks-grows-65-yoy-surpasses-5-4-billion-revenue-run-rate-doubles-down-on-lakebase-and-genie-302682674.html), the annualized run rate reached $5.4 billion in the January quarter, up 65 percent year-over-year. Products tied directly to artificial intelligence now generate $1.4 billion in annualized revenue. Databricks also disclosed that it generated positive free cash flow over the past twelve months — a relatively rare milestone for a private software company at this scale and growth rate.

The result is a company now substantially larger by revenue than its closest public comparable: Snowflake, which reported $1.21 billion in revenue in its most recent quarter and carries a market capitalization of roughly $58 billion, according to [CNBC](https://www.cnbc.com/2026/02/09/databricks-completes-5-billion-funding-round-with-2-billion-in-debt.html).

## Lakebase: A PostgreSQL for the Agent Era

The product that most directly explains Databricks' accelerating revenue growth is Lakebase, which reached general availability on February 2, 2026. The service is a fully managed, serverless implementation of PostgreSQL, but its design priorities depart sharply from those of a traditional relational database.

As [InfoQ reported](https://www.infoq.com/news/2026/02/databricks-lakebase-postgresql/), Lakebase is built to sit at the center of agentic AI workflows — serving as the system of record for agent state, session memory, configuration, and real-time decisioning. Where a conventional database is optimized for transactional integrity or analytical throughput in isolation, Lakebase aims to unify all three modes: online transactional processing (OLTP), analytics, and AI workloads on a single governed foundation.

The architectural bet reflects a genuine operational problem. Teams building AI agents currently stitch together separate systems: a vector database for embeddings, a relational database for structured records, a streaming system for real-time inputs, and an analytics engine for retrospective queries. Each layer introduces latency, consistency risk, and operational overhead. According to the [Databricks blog](https://www.databricks.com/blog/databricks-lakebase-generally-available), Lakebase is designed to collapse those layers by integrating directly with the Databricks Data Intelligence Platform and Unity Catalog, giving agents a governed, query-consistent view of enterprise data without requiring engineers to manage topology across disparate systems.

The PostgreSQL wire compatibility is strategic: applications already built on Postgres — the world's most widely deployed open-source relational database — can migrate to Lakebase with minimal friction while gaining the auto-scaling and serverless billing model of a cloud-native service.

## Genie and the Conversational Data Layer

Running alongside Lakebase is Genie, Databricks' AI/BI assistant that allows employees to ask natural-language questions about enterprise data without writing SQL or constructing dashboards. Genie has been in preview since 2024, but recent updates formalize its enterprise readiness.

New capabilities include Conversation APIs in public preview that let developers embed Genie's query logic into external applications, and Model Context Protocol (MCP) integrations that allow third-party AI assistants to query Databricks workspaces securely. As detailed in the [Databricks February AI/BI roundup](https://www.databricks.com/blog/whats-new-aibi-february-2026-roundup), Genie spaces can now be tracked in Unity Catalog lineage, enabling governance teams to audit which conversational agents have access to which datasets — a requirement for regulated industries deploying AI on sensitive data.

Together, Lakebase and Genie reflect a coherent architectural thesis: that the next generation of enterprise software is not built around a static data warehouse or a separate BI tool, but around a continuous, conversational, agent-driven layer that sits directly on top of unified operational and analytical data.

## Competitive Positioning

The $134 billion valuation and $7 billion war chest position Databricks to accelerate on multiple fronts simultaneously. The company has described Lakebase as a direct challenge to incumbent transactional databases from Oracle and SAP — markets far larger than the analytics segment where Databricks originally established itself. If Lakebase achieves meaningful penetration in operational database workloads, it would transform Databricks from a specialized analytics vendor into a horizontal data platform competing across the entire enterprise stack.

On the AI infrastructure side, $1.4 billion in AI-specific annualized revenue is substantial evidence that demand for agentic infrastructure is converting from pilot to production. The decision to build Lakebase as the persistence layer for agents appears to be resonating with enterprise buyers who want to avoid the complexity of maintaining separate vector, relational, and streaming databases for each AI application.

## What We Don't Know

Several significant questions remain open. On IPO timing, CEO Ali Ghodsi has been deliberately noncommittal, telling reporters the company is prepared to go public "when the time is right" while indicating it is comfortable remaining private if market conditions are unfavorable. With $7 billion in fresh capital and positive free cash flow, there is no immediate pressure to access public markets.

The competitive response from Snowflake, Google, Microsoft, and Amazon — all of which have launched or are building AI-native database and analytics products — remains to be fully played out. Each major cloud provider has native advantages in distribution and bundling that Databricks, as an independent vendor, does not.

And the actual performance of Lakebase at scale has yet to be validated across the full diversity of large enterprise workloads. The assertion that a single serverless Postgres service can adequately serve as the persistence layer for production AI agents — replacing specialized vector, streaming, and relational systems — is an ambitious claim that the coming months of broad adoption will test.
